skill.name: chronicle-context-retriever
skill.description: Search and retrieve context from past development sessions using Chronicle data. Works with MCP (fast, structured) or CLI commands (portable). Use when user asks about previous work, wants to recall past decisions, needs to understand codebase history, or wants to avoid repeating past approaches.
skill.summary: Search and retrieve context from past development sessions using Chronicle data. Works with MCP (fas...
skill.author: ChandlerHardy

security_audit.summary: This skill is a pure documentation file (SKILL.md) with no executable code, network calls, or file system access. It only provides instructions for using existing Chronicle MCP tools and CLI commands. All 77 static findings are false positives triggered by the static analyzer misinterpreting documentation elements (markdown code backticks, example paths, and documentation terminology) as security threats.

content.user_title: Search Your Development History with Chronicle
content.value_statement: Stop repeating past mistakes and rediscover solutions you have already implemented. This skill searches your Chronicle database to find relevant context from previous development sessions. Build on past work instead of starting from scratch.
actual_capabilities: Search Chronicle database for past development sessions
Retrieve session summaries and key decisions
Find implementation approaches from previous work
Identify blockers and solutions from past sessions
Search by keywords, time periods, or repositories
Access both MCP tools and CLI commands
limitations: Requires Chronicle to be installed and configured
Cannot access sessions from other users
Search results depend on Chronicle summarization quality
MCP tools must be configured for fastest performance

use_cases.title: Recall Past Implementations
use_cases.description: Quickly find how you solved similar problems before, including decisions made and issues encountered.

use_cases.title: Get Project Context
use_cases.description: Understand what work was done while you were away, including recent decisions and current blockers.

use_cases.title: Learn from Past Blockers
use_cases.description: Identify what blocked progress previously and how it was resolved to avoid hitting the same issues again.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Session Search
prompt_templates.scenario: Find recent work on a topic
prompt_templates.prompt: Search my Chronicle sessions for work on authentication implementation in the last 2 weeks

prompt_templates.title: Problem-Solution Lookup
prompt_templates.scenario: Find how a blocker was solved
prompt_templates.prompt: What was the blocker we hit with the database migration and how did we solve it?

prompt_templates.title: Implementation Recall
prompt_templates.prompt: How did I implement the user-dashboard feature? Show me the approach and key decisions

prompt_templates.title: Pattern Discovery
prompt_templates.prompt: Search for all sessions about API performance issues and summarize the common patterns

output_examples.input: What did I do yesterday regarding the authentication system?
output: Key decisions: Used Auth0 instead of custom solution
Blockers: CORS issues with frontend integration
Solutions: Added proper headers and proxy configuration

best_practices: Start with broad searches to find relevant areas, then narrow down with specific terms
Use both MCP tools for structured JSON output and CLI commands for portable access
Review failed sessions too - they often contain valuable lessons about what to avoid
anti_patterns: Do not rely solely on memory - search Chronicle first before reinventing solutions
Avoid searching only for successful sessions - failed attempts often contain valuable lessons
Do not skip the deep-dive phase after initial broad searches

faq.question: Do I need Chronicle installed to use this skill?
faq.answer: Yes, this skill searches your Chronicle database. Install Chronicle first and ensure it is tracking your sessions.

faq.question: What is the difference between MCP and CLI approaches?
faq.answer: MCP provides structured JSON responses and is faster, while CLI works everywhere as a reliable fallback option.

faq.question: How far back can I search?
faq.answer: You can search all sessions in your Chronicle database from any time period since you started tracking.

faq.question: Is my session data safe?
faq.answer: Yes, Chronicle stores data locally on your machine. This skill only accesses your own local database.

faq.question: What if MCP tools are not working?
faq.answer: Use the CLI commands as a fallback. The skill provides both approaches for maximum compatibility.

faq.question: Can I search other people is sessions?
faq.answer: No, you can only search sessions from your own Chronicle database on your local machine.
